Later in the west the title was retained as a name.Bajpai, R.S. (2002) Atlantic Publishers, The Splendours And Dimensions of Yoga 2 Vols. Set, page 554, "received the title Maharishi, from some Indian Pundits" He traveled around India for two years{{Cite book|title=Thirty Years Around the World: Dawn of the Age of Enlightenment|publisher=Maharishi Vedic University Press|year=1986|author=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi|isbn=90-71750-02-7|page=199}} {{Request quotation|date=May 2010}}Mason (1994) pp. 27–34 interacting with his "Hindu audiences" in an "Indian context".{{cite book | title=The Religious Melting Point: On Tolerance, Controversdial Religions and The State | publisher=Tectum Verlag Marburg | author=Gablinger, Tamar | authorlink=| year=2010 | location=Germany | pages=76}} At that time, he called his movement the Spiritual Development Movement, but renamed it the [[Spiritual Regeneration Movement]] in 1957, in [[Madras]], India, on the concluding day of the Seminar of Spiritual Luminaries.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-maharishi6feb06,1,4208394.story|last=Woo|first=Elaine|title=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi|work=Los Angeles Times|date=6 February 2006}} According to Coplin, in his visits to southern India, the Maharishi spoke English rather than the [[Hindi]] spoken in his home area to avoid provoking resistance among those seeking linguistic self-determination, and to appeal to the "learned classes".{{Cite thesis |degree= PhD|chapter=Chapter Two: Socio-Historical Context for SRM's Emergence |title=Text and Context in the Communication of a Social Movement's Charisma, Ideology, and Consciousness: TM for India and the West |url= |author= |last=Coplin |first=J.R. |year= 1990|publisher=University of California, San Diego |accessdate= |docket= |oclc= |quote=In South India Maharishi spoke in English because his Hindi would not only be little understood outside of the North, but it would provoke hostility among many who were fighting for linguistic self-determination in the period immediately following Independence. The use of English, however, had greater connotations, as it presumed an audience of Indians familiar with British administration and education. More significantly, it appealed to the 'learned classes', mostly brahmins, but also lower caste officials whose families had escaped their more humble backgrounds by means of acquiring an English education.}} ===World tours (1958–1968)=== According to author William Jefferson, in 1958, the Maharishi went to Madras to address a large crowd of people who had gathered to celebrate the memory of Guru Dev. It was there that he spontaneously announced that he planned to spread the teaching of TM throughout the world. Hundreds of people immediately asked to learn TM. In 1959, Maharishi Mahesh Yogi began his first world tour, writing: "I had one thing in mind, that I know something which is useful to every man". The Maharishi's 1986 book, ''Thirty Years Around the World'', gives a detailed account of his world tours, as do two biographies, ''The Story of the Maharishi'', by William Jefferson, and ''The Maharishi'' by Paul Mason. The first world tour began in Rangoon, [[Burma]] (now [[Myanmar]]) and included the countries of Thailand, [[British Malaya|Malaya]], Singapore, Hong Kong and Hawaii.{{Cite web|publisher=One India|title=Naturally in Self; Maharishi Mahesh Yogi|first=Priya|last=Devi|date=21 February 2008|url=http://living.oneindia.in/yoga-spirituality/faith-mysticism/2008/maharishi-mahesh-yogi-profile-death.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725124423/http://living.oneindia.in/yoga-spirituality/faith-mysticism/2008/maharishi-mahesh-yogi-profile-death.html|archivedate=25 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 237 "Summary 1958: The first countries he visited on his first world tour were Burma, Thailand, Malaya, Singapore, Hong Kong and the USA (Hawaii)."Mason, p. 34 (1994) He arrived in Hawaii in the spring of 1959 and the ''[[Honolulu Star Bulletin]]'' reported: "He has no money, he asks for nothing. His worldly possessions can be carried in one hand. Maharishi Mahesh Yogi is on a world odyssey. He carries a message that he says will rid the world of all unhappiness and discontent."Mason, p. 37 (1994) "He has no money; he asks for nothing. His worldly possessions can be carried in one hand. Maharishi Mahesh Yogi is on a world odyssey. He carries a message that he says will rid the world of all unhappiness and discontent..." In 1959, the Maharishi lectured and taught the Transcendental Meditation technique in Honolulu, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Boston, New York and London.Mason, pp. 41–46 (1994){{Cite web| last =Blume| first =Mary| title =A Little Meditation on the Bottom Line| publisher =International New York Times| date = 8 July 1995| url =https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/08/style/08iht-yoga.t.html| accessdate = 2013-11-26 }}Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 275 "Summary 1959: In January Maharishi travelled to the [mainland] USA for the first time, establishing the movement in Hawaii and then moving on to San Francisco and Los Angeles. Towards the end of the year, he once again visited Hawaii, then flew to the East Coast cities of Boston and New York" While in Los Angeles the Maharishi stayed at the home of author Helena Olson,Olson, Helena, ''Hermit in the House'', p. 44, Los Angeles, 1967 {{Unreliable source?|date=August 2010}} and during this period he developed a three-year plan to propagate Transcendental Meditation to the whole world. Though most of his audience consisted of average middle class individuals, he also attracted a few celebrities, such as [[Efrem Zimbalist Jr.]], [[Nancy Cooke de Herrera]] and [[Doris Duke]]. [[File:MichaelCooper1967BenMerk.jpg|{{largethumb}}|Left to right: [[Michael Cooper (photographer)|Michael Cooper]], [[Mick Jagger]], [[Marianne Faithfull]], [[Al Vandenberg]] & [[Brian Jones]]; sitting: Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (Concertgebouw Amsterdam, 1967)]] When the Maharishi came to the U.S. in 1959, his Spiritual Regeneration Movement was called Transcendental Meditation. That same year he began the International Meditation Society and other organizations to propagate his teachings,{{Cite book| last1 = Hunt | first1 = Stephen | authorlink=Stephen J. Hunt|title = Alternative religions: a sociological introduction | year = 2003 | publisher = Ashgate | location = Aldershot, Hampshire, England ; Burlington, VT | isbn = 978-0-7546-3410-2 | pages = 197–198|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0GuWbJhYIccC&pg=PA197&dq=transcendental+meditation&q=transcendental%20meditation }} establishing centres in San Francisco and London. For years, the sole teacher of Transcendental Meditation in America was a San Diego woman named Beulah Smith. In 1960, the Maharishi travelled to many cities in India, France, Switzerland, England, Scotland, Norway, Sweden, Germany, the Netherlands, Italy, Singapore, Australia, New Zealand and Africa.Mason, pp. 52–54 (1994)Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) pp. 318–320 Note: The source contains a 3-page itinerary of 40+ cities visited by the Maharishi with corresponding dates of visit ranging from 1/1/60 and 12/30/60, "Summary 1960: Maharishi brought TM to the countries of Europe and in his many lectures in England, Scotland, Norway, and Germany he...""In the first half of the year he visited France, Switzerland, Austria and Germany." "...then travelled to the Scandinavian countries of Norway, Denmark and Sweden." While in [[Manchester]], England, the Maharishi gave a television interview and was featured in many English newspapers such as the ''[[Birmingham Post]]'', the ''[[Oxford Mail]]'' and the ''[[Cambridge Daily News]]''.Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 305 "In Manchester, Maharishi gave a television interview which reached millions of people in the north of England" "In Cambridge, the Daily News carried headline: 'Maharishi shows a simple method of meditation', while the Oxford Mail reporter who asked Maharishi ...." This was also the year in which the Maharishi trained Henry Nyburg to be the first Transcendental Meditation teacher in Europe.Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 302 "Maharishi made Henry Nyburg his personal representative for Europe and gave him the training and authority to teach Transcendental Meditation, thus making him the first European teacher."Mason, p. 52 (1994) In 1961, the Maharishi visited the United States, Austria, Sweden, France, Italy, Greece, India, Kenya, England, and Canada.Mason, pp. 54–55 (1994) While in England, he appeared on [[BBC]] television and gave a lecture to 5,000 people at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London.Mason, p. 55 (1994) In April 1961, the Maharishi conducted his first Transcendental Meditation Teacher Training Course in [[Rishikesh]], India, with sixty participants from various countries.Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) pp. 318–344 "From Chapter Titled '1961' pg 328 "The following day, BBC Television interviewed Maharishi and chose as the setting for the interview the Acropolis, one of the glories of ancient Greece." "On 20 April Maharishi inaugurated... Maharishi then conducted the first international course to train teacher of TM" "The graduation ceremony of the course was held on 12 July and 60 new teachers of TM returned to their countries...." Teachers continued to be trained as time progressed.{{cite web|url=http://enlightenmenthow.com/maharishi-and-the-7-step-teachers-program/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005062737/http://enlightenmenthow.com/maharishi-and-the-7-step-teachers-program/ |archivedate=5 October 2016 |df=dmy }} During the course, the Maharishi began to introduce additional knowledge regarding the development of human potential, and began writing his translation and commentary on the first six chapters of the ancient Vedic text, the [[Bhagavad Gita]].Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 400 "...it was on this course that Maharishi started his commentary on the Bhagavad Gita – a commentary later to be published..."Mason, p. 62, 69 (1994) His 1962 world tour included visits to Europe, India, Australia and New Zealand.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} In Britain, he founded a branch of the Spiritual Regeneration Movement. The year concluded in California where the Maharishi began dictating his book ''The Science of Being and Art of Living''.Mason, p. 62 (1994)Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 490-491 and p. 503 "And in the final days of 1962, in the silent surroundings of Lake Arrowhead, California, Maharishi brought out yet another gift for the world – The Science of Being and Art of Living – a treasury of pure knowledge to guide mankind in its evolution to perfection." In Rishikesh, India, beginning on 20 April 1962, a forty-day course was held for "sadhus, sanyasis, and brahmacharis" to introduce TM to "religious preachers and spiritual masters in India".Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 414 "Chapter Titled "1962": On 20 April, Maharishi in the presence of His Holiness Swami Shantanand Saraswati, the Shankaracharya of northern India, inaugurated a special course" "In the Prospectus, this special 40-day course was announced for 'sadhus, sannyasis and brahmacharis, and retired persons of energetic calibre'." The Maharishi toured cities in Europe, Asia, North America and India in 1963, and also addressed ministers of the [[Indian Parliament]].Mason, pp. 66–67 (1994)Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) pp. 544–545 "Twenty one members of the parliament, representing each of the Indian states, issued a statement entitled a 'timely Call to the Leaders of Today and Tomorrow' for the speedy introduction of the system [of TM] into the daily routine of national life." NOTE: the text of the 3-page statement from the parliament is also included in the book on pages 504–507 According to his memoirs, twenty-one members of parliament then issued a public statement endorsing the Maharishi's goals and meditation technique.Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 504-507 "Twenty one members of parliament, representing each of the Indian states, issued a statement entitled a 'timely Call to the Leaders of Today and Tomorrow' for the speedy introduction of the system [of TM] into the daily routine of national life." NOTE: the text of the 3-page statement from the parliament is also included in the book on pages 504–507 His Canadian tourMason, p. 69 (1994) was also well covered by the press.Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 530-536 "Tributes were later printed in the Canadian magazine, Enjoy"--"A front page news article in the local Daily Colonist newspaper" "The Calgary Herald reported an entertaining incident, which took place during an interview in Maharishi's hotel room". "The Albertan newspaper of Wednesday, 25 September quoted Maharishi as saying that there were now 1,000 TM meditators in Canada." The Maharishi's fifth world tour, in 1964, consisted of visits to many cities in North America, Europe and India.Mason, pp. 71–75 (1994)Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) pp 587–588 "On his fifth world tour, Maharishi conducted a Meditation Guides Course in Norway, a course in London, where advanced techniques of TM were given for the first time, and Meditation Guides Courses in Austria, Canada, and Germany/" During his visit to England, he appeared with the [[Abbot]] of [[Downside Abbey|Downside]], Abbot Butler, on a BBC television show called ''The Viewpoint''.Mason, p. 72 (1994)Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 553 "But the highlight of this London visit was the popular BBC television interview with Robert Kee, featuring Maharishi and the Abbot of Downside, Abbot Butler." In October of that year, in California, the Maharishi began teaching the first Advanced Technique of Transcendental Meditation to some experienced meditators.Mason, p. 75 (1994)Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) p. 572 "On his fifth world tour, Maharishi conducted a Meditation Guides Course in Norway, a course in London, where advanced techniques of TM were given for the first time, and Meditation Guides Courses in Austria, Canada, and Germany" While travelling in America, the Maharishi met with [[Robert Maynard Hutchins]], the head of the [[Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions]], and [[U Thant]], the [[Secretary General of the United Nations]].Mason, p. 79 (1994)Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (1986) pp 576–577 "On the 17th Maharishi went to Santa Barbara to meet with Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, head of the Centre for Democratic Studies. Maharishi left for NYC on 19 December to meet with U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations." During this same year, the Maharishi finished his book ''The Science of Being and Art of Living'', which sold more than a million copies and was published in fifteen languages. In 1966, the Maharishi founded the Students' International Meditation Society ("SIMS"), which ''The Los Angeles Times'' later characterised as a "phenomenal success". In the 1970s, SIMS centres were established at "over one thousand campuses",Olson, Carl (1 January 2005) Transcendental Meditation, ''Encyclopedia of Religion'' including [[Harvard University]], Yale University, and [[UCLA]]. In 1967, the Maharishi gave a lecture at [[Caxton Hall]] in London which was attended by [[Pattie Boyd]], [[George Harrison]]'s wife, as well as [[Leon MacLaren]], the founder and leader of the [[School of Economic Science]] (SES).{{rp|22}} He also lectured at UCLA, Harvard, Yale and Berkeley.Bainbridge, William Sims (1997 Routledge, ''The Sociology of Religious Movements'', page 188 That year, an article in ''Time'' magazine reported that the Maharishi "has been sharply criticised by other Indian sages, who complain that his programme for spiritual peace without either penance or asceticism contravenes every traditional Hindu belief".{{cite news|title=Mystics: Soothsayer for Everyman|date=20 October 1967|work=Time magazine|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,902143,00.html}} Religion and culture scholar Sean McCloud also reported that traditional Indian sages and gurus were critical of the Maharishi, for teaching a simple technique and making it available to everyone, and for abandoning traditional concepts of suffering and concentration as paths to enlightenment.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X50EHT0eiEwC&pg=PA106&dq=maharishi+inauthentic&cd=2#v=onepage&q=maharishi%20inauthentic&f=false |last=McCloud|first=Sean|title=Making the American Religious Fringe: Exotics, Subersives and Journalists, 1955–1993|publisher=UNC Press|year=2004|isbn=978-0-8078-5496-9}} At the end of 1968, the Maharishi said that after ten years of teaching and world tours, he would return to India.{{Cite book | edition = [1st ed.]. | publisher = Doubleday | last = Needleman | first = Jacob | title = The New Religions| location = Garden City N.Y. | year = 1970|chapter=Transcendental Meditation|pages=139–155}} ===Association with the Beatles=== {{Main|The Beatles in Bangor|The Beatles in India}} In 1967, the Maharishi's fame increased and his movement gained greater prominence when he became the "spiritual advisor to [[the Beatles]]",{{cite news|title=Beatles Guru Maharishi Mahesh Yogi Dies|date=5 February 2008|url=http://news.smh.com.au/world/beatles-guru-maharishi-mahesh-yogi-dies-20080206-1qno.html|first=Stephanie|last=van den Berg|agency=AFP|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|archivedate=30 August 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sMh9UTba?url=http://news.smh.com.au/world/beatles-guru-maharishi-mahesh-yogi-dies-20080206-1qno.html|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|first=Mike|last=Corder|title=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi; The Beatles' mentor had global empire|work=The San Diego Union-Tribune|date=10 February 2008|url=http://sports.uniontrib.com/uniontrib/20080210/news_1c10yogi.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sMeexJGb?url=http://sports.uniontrib.com/uniontrib/20080210/news_1c10yogi.html|archivedate=30 August 2010|agency=Associated Press|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} though he was already well known among young people in the UK and had already had numerous public appearances that brought him to the band's attention.{{Cite book|last=Humes|first=C.A.|year=2005|chapter=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi: Beyond the T.M. Technique|title=Gurus in America|editor1-first=Thomas A. |editor1-last=Forsthoefel |editor2-first=Cynthia Ann |editor2-last=Humes|publisher=SUNY Press|page=64|isbn=0-7914-6573-X |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ugSb7mArJlYC&q=beatles#v=snippet&q=beatles&f=false}} Following the Beatles' endorsement of TM, during 1967 and 1968 the Maharishi appeared on American magazine covers such as ''Life'', ''Newsweek'', ''Time'' and many others.{{Cite book | edition = [1st ed.]. | publisher = Doubleday | last = Needleman | first = Jacob | title = The New Religions| location = Garden City N.Y. | year = 1970|chapter=Transcendental Meditation|pages=139}} He gave lectures to capacity crowds at the [[Felt Forum]] in New York City and Harvard's Sanders Hall. He also appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' and the ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]'' TV shows. He and the Beatles met in London in August 1967 and the band members went to study with the Maharishi in [[Bangor, Gwynedd|Bangor]], Wales, before travelling to Rishikesh, India, in February 1968 to "devote themselves fully to his instruction".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/07/arts/music/07yogi.html|work=New York Times|first=Allan |last=Kozinn |title=Meditation on the Man Who Saved the Beatles|date=7 February 2008}} [[Ringo Starr]] and his wife [[Maureen Starkey|Maureen]] left after ten days,{{cite book|author=Barry Miles|title=Paul McCartney: many years from now|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-eh8BedNtLgC&pg=PA412|accessdate=6 October 2011|year=1998|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-8050-5249-7|pages=412–}}{{cite web|url=http://www.beatlesbible.com/1968/03/01/ringo-starr-leaves-india/|title=Ringo Starr Leaves India|accessdate=2011-10-04}} [[Paul McCartney]] and [[Jane Asher]] left after five weeks;{{cite book |last=Miles |first=Barry |authorlink=Barry Miles |year=2007 |title=The Beatles Diary: An Intimate Day by Day History |publisher=World Publications Group |location=East Bridgewater, MA |pages=262–63 |isbn=1-57215-010-6}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kkXNECitum0C|last=Miles|first=Barry|title=Paul McCartney: Many Years from Now|publisher=Macmillan|year=1998|isbn=978-0-8050-5249-7|page=427}}{{cite book |title=The Beatles Anthology |publisher=Chronicle Books |year=2000 |place=San Francisco |isbn=0-8118-2684-8 |pages=284–85}} the group's most dedicated students, [[George Harrison]] and [[John Lennon]], departed with their wives sixteen days later. During their stay, the Beatles heard that the Maharishi had allegedly made sexual advances towards [[Mia Farrow]].{{Cite book|title=''Lennon Remembers''|page=27|publisher=Verso, W.W. Norton & Co.|last=Wenner|first=Jann|authorlink=Jann_Wenner|year=2000|origyear=1971|isbn=1-85984-376-X|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ymjy06WZnd4C&pg=RA1-PA27&dq=%22lennon+remembers%22+maharishi&sig=Z-ZRmuOd3HN0av5kTK6IuemPGTY|quote=Yeah, there was a big hullabaloo about him trying to rape Mia Farrow or trying to get off with Mia Farrow and a few other women, things like that.}} On June 15, 1968, in London, the Beatles formally renounced their association with the Maharishi as a "public mistake". "[[Sexy Sadie]]" is the name of a song by the Beatles, written by Lennon in India and credited to Lennon–McCartney.{{Cite book| edition = 1St| publisher = Little, Brown and Company| isbn = 0-316-80352-9| last = Spitz| first = Bob| title = The Beatles: The Biography| date = 1 November 2005|page=757}}{{Cite book|title=[[Revolution in the Head: The Beatles' Records and the Sixties]] |edition=3rd revised |first=Ian |last=MacDonald |year=2007 |publisher=[[Chicago Review Press]] |isbn=1-84413-828-3}} Lennon originally wanted to title the song "Maharishi",{{cite book |last=Harry |first=Bill |authorlink=Bill Harry |title=The Book of Beatle Lists |publisher=Javelin |year=1985 |isbn=0-7137-1521-9}} but changed the title at Harrison's request. Harrison commented years later, "Now, historically, there's the story that something went on that shouldn't have done – but nothing did." In 1992, Harrison gave a benefit concert for the Maharishi-associated Natural Law Party, and later apologised for the way the Maharishi had been treated by saying, "We were very young" and "It's probably in the history books that Maharishi 'tried to attack Mia Farrow' – but it's bullshit, total bullshit." Cynthia Lennon wrote in 2006 that she "hated leaving on a note of discord and mistrust, when we had enjoyed so much kindness from the Maharishi". Asked if he forgave the Beatles, the Maharishi replied, "I could never be upset with angels." McCartney took his daughter, Stella, to visit the Maharishi in the Netherlands in 2007, which renewed their friendship.[46][188]{{clarify|reason=Two citations here are typed rather than using proper markup. They are likely to be incorrect, and should be checked and corrected.|date=June 2018}}{{Cite book|title=The Beatles Anthology|publisher=Chronicle Books|year=2000|pages=285–86|isbn=0-8118-2684-8}} The ''New York Times'' and ''The Independent'' reported that the influence of the Maharishi, and the journey to Rishikesh to meditate, weaned the Beatles from LSD and inspired them to write many new songs.{{cite news|work=Artistic Yoga|title=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi: Spiritual leader who introduced millions, including the Beatles, to transcendental meditation|date=7 February 2008|first=Spencer|last=Leigh|url=http://www.artistic-yoga.com/maharishi-mahesh-yogi-spiritual-leader-introduced-millions-including-beatles-transcendental-meditation|location=London|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141206062120/http://www.artistic-yoga.com/maharishi-mahesh-yogi-spiritual-leader-introduced-millions-including-beatles-transcendental-meditation|archivedate=6 December 2014|df=dmy-all}} In 2009, McCartney commented that Transcendental Meditation was a gift the Beatles had received from the Maharishi at a time when they were looking for something to stabilise them.{{cite news|last=Nichols|first=Michelle|title=McCartney says meditation helped stabilize Beatles|work=Reuters|date=3 April 2009|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE53264920090403}} The Beatles' visit to the Maharishi's ashram coincided with a thirty-participant Transcendental Meditation teacher training course that was ongoing when they arrived. Graduates of the course included [[Prudence Farrow]] and [[Mike Love]].Russell, Peter (1976) Routledge & Kegan Paul Ltd, page pp26-30{{cite news|title=How the real 'Dear Prudence' in John Lennon's song inspired me|first=David|last=Magee|work=Chattanooga Times Free Press|date=17 October 2009|page=B.1}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pophistorydig.com/?tag=beatles-prudence-farrow|title= Dear Prudence, 1967–1968|first=Jack|last=Doyle|publisher=PopHistoryDig.com|date=27 July 2009|accessdate=15 May 2010}} Although the Rishakesh ashram had thrived in its early days it was eventually abandoned in 2001. By 2016, some of it had been reclaimed with building repairs, cleared paths, a small photo museum, murals, a cafe and charges for visitors although the site remains essentially a ruin.{{cite news |title=Beatles Indian hideaway - 50 years on |url=https://www.livemint.com/Consumer/EyPaee8GcEd0nVvZG0xagO/Beatles-Indian-hideaway-comes-together-50-years-on.html?utm_source=scroll&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=scroll |accessdate=13 August 2018 |publisher=Live Mint |date=13 August 2018}} ===Further growth of the TM movement (1968–1990)=== [[File:Picswiss UR-28-18.jpg|thumb|left|The Maharishi's headquarters in [[Seelisberg]], Switzerland]] In 1968, the Maharishi announced that he would stop his public activities and instead begin the training of TM teachers at his new global headquarters in [[Seelisberg]], Switzerland. In 1969, he inaugurated a course in his Science of Creative Intelligence at [[Stanford University]], which was then offered at 25 other American universities. In 1970, the Maharishi held a TM teacher training course at a Victorian hotel in [[Poland, Maine|Poland Springs, Maine]], with 1,200 participants. Later that year, he held a similar four-week course with 1500 participants at [[Humboldt State College]] in [[Arcata, California]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rqIgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fGgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3160,277023&dq=maharishi&hl=en|work=Lewiston Evening Journal|agency=Associated Press |first=Pat |last=Sherlock|date=3 July 1970|title=The Transcendental Gospel Solution to Life's Problems Says Guru at Poland Springs}} In 1970, after having trouble with Indian tax authorities, he moved his headquarters to Italy, returning to India in the late 1970s.{{cite book |first1=Constance |last1=Jones |first2=James |last2=Ryan |title=Encyclopedia of Hinduism |year=2007 |publisher=Facts on File |location=New York City |page=273 |quote=The Maharishi returned to India in the late 1970s and moved to the Netherlands in 1990.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OgMmceadQ3gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=encyclopedia+of+hinduism&hl=en&sa=X&ei=dmk7UanpDvSO2QX-1oCYDA&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=mahesh%20yogi&f=false}}{{cite news|work=The Telegraph|date=7 February 2008|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1577870/Maharishi-Mahesh-Yogi.html | location=London | title=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi}} That same year, the [[City of Hope National Medical Center|City of Hope Foundation]] in Los Angeles gave the Maharishi their "Man of Hope" award.Goldhaber, Nat, Denniston, Denise, McWilliams, Peter, (1976). '' TM: an alphabetical guide to the transcendental meditation program'', p. 109. Ballantine, New York. {{ISBN|0-345-24096-0}} Note: "It was in honor of his great contribution to humankind that Maharishi was named Man of Hope in 1970 by the City of Hope Foundation in Los Angeles". By 1971, the Maharishi had completed 13 world tours, visited 50 countries, and held a press conference with American inventor [[Buckminster Fuller]] at his first International Symposium on SCI at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst, Massachusetts.Williamson, Lola (2012) New York University Press, Transcendent in America, pp 80–105 (page 92){{cite web |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/online/wolcott/2010/09/how-pleasing-and-inspiring-it.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529201445/http://www.vanityfair.com/online/wolcott/2010/09/how-pleasing-and-inspiring-it.html |archivedate=29 May 2011 |df=dmy }} Vanity Fair, Beam Me Up, Bucky, James Walcott, 15 September 2010{{YouTube|6z8u313eY_c|Maharishi Channel}} From 1970 to 1973, about 10,000 people attended the Maharishi sponsored symposia on his modern interpretation of Vedanta philosophy called Science of Creative Intelligence. During these conferences, held at universities, the Maharishi spoke with "leading thinkers" of the day such as [[Hans Selye]], [[Marshall McLuhan]], and [[Jonas Salk]]. The Maharishi announced his World Plan in 1972, the goal of which was to establish 3,600 TM centres around the world. That year, a TM training course was given by the Maharishi at [[Queen's University]] and was attended by 1,000 young people from the USA and Canada. At the start of the course, the Maharishi encouraged the attendees to improve their appearance by getting haircuts and wearing ties.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BQsyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=w6EFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3772,310478&dq=maharishi&hl=en|title=Maharishi tells Queen's student to continue short-hair culture|agency=CP|work=Montreal Gazette|date=2 August 1972}} He also persuaded the U.S. Army to offer courses in TM to its soldiers and made videotaped recordings of what was thought to be the West's first comprehensive recitation of the [[Rig Veda]].Stark, Rodney and Bainbridge, William Sims (1985) University of California Press, The Future of Religion, page 288 In March 1973, the Maharishi addressed the legislature of the state of Illinois. That same year, the legislature passed a resolution in support of the use of Maharishi's Science of Creative Intelligence in Illinois public schools.[https://archive.is/20130115114017/http://news.google.ca/newspapers?id=kyIrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XZ4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3743,2143748&dq=maharishi+illinois+legislature&hl=en] "People", ''[[Anchorage Daily News]]'', 1973-03-14. Note: "The Maharishi addressed the Illinois legislature Tuesday and made a few suggestions on how to handle fiscal problems. "The basis of a restful budget is no problems in society", he told legislators. Retrieved on 2010-12-01.[https://archive.is/20120713103217/http://news.google.ca/newspapers?id=kW8zAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oTgHAAAAIBAJ&pg=3048,1889826&dq=maharishi+illinois+legislature&hl=en] "The TM believers are expanding their universe", ''[[Bangor Daily News]]'', 6 March 1973. Note: "The legislature in the State of Illinois passed a resolution this past year recommending the inclusion of SCI teaching in the public schools." Retrieved on 2010-12-01. Later that year he organized a world conference of mayors in Switzerland. In that same year, he also addressed 3000 educators at an American Association of Higher Education (AAHE) conference on quality of life and higher education. In 1974, the [[Maharishi International University]] was founded. In October 1975, the Maharishi was pictured on the front cover of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine. He made his last visit to the [[Spiritual Regeneration Movement]] centre in Los Angeles in 1975, according to film director [[David Lynch]], who met him for the first time there.{{cite news|title=David Lynch's Guru and His Art| date=7 February 2008|first=Claire|last=Hoffman|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=1 May 2010|url=http://newsweek.washingtonpost.com/onfaith/undergod/2008/02/david_lynch_talks_about_the_de.html}} In 1975, the Maharishi embarked on a five-continent trip to inaugurate what he called "the Dawn of the Age of Enlightenment". The Maharishi said the purpose of the inaugural tour was to "go around the country and give a gentle whisper to the population".{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_woyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=16EFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4101,1947773&dq=maharishi&hl=en|work=Montreal Gazette|date=24 March 1975|first=Don |last=McPherson|title=Maharishi Claims Meditation Push Can Help Canada}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9tMjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NlgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6135,3689323&dq=maharishi&hl=en|work=The Evening Independent|date=27 March 1975|title=Maharishi Carries Roses, Quiets World|first=Bethia |last=Caffery}} He visited Ottawa during this tour and had a private meeting with Canadian prime minister Pierre Trudeau, during which he spoke about the principles of TM and "the possibility of structuring an ideal society".[https://archive.is/20120713193148/http://news.google.ca/newspapers?id=3-BYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b1IMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4744,1878994&dq=trudeau+maharishi&hl=en] "Maharishi says Trudeau 'Receptive'", ''Canadian Press'', ''[[The Windsor Star]]'', 1975-03-22. Retrieved on 2010-10-21.The Gazette, 22 March 1975, "PM and TM leader"The Citizen, 22 March 1975, "Trudeau "intelligent man" Guru Says After Long Talk" That same year, the Pittsburgh Press reported that "The Maharishi has been criticised by other Eastern yogis for simplifying their ancient art."{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sAscAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r1UEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7353,3712907&dq=maharishi+criticized+hindus&hl=en |last=Gigler|first=Rich|title=Transcendental Meditation can be relaxing hobby|work=Pittsburgh Press|date=10 February 1975}} The Maharishi appeared as a guest on ''[[The Merv Griffin Show]]'' in 1975 and again in 1977, and this resulted in "tens of thousands of new practitioners" around the USA.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/the-merv-griffin-show/december-14-1977/episode/1141200/summary.html?tag=episode_header;next|title=The Merv Griffin Show: December 14, 1977|publisher=TV.com web site|accessdate=30 December 2009}}{{cite news|title=Flighty Lawsuit Has Lousy Karma|first=Mike|last= Royko|authorlink=Mike Royko|work=Chicago Tribune |date=13 September 1985|page=3}}Merv: making the good life last, Merv Griffin, David Bender, page 177 [[File:Maharishi Mahesh Yogi during a 1979 visit to MUM.jpg|thumb|200px|The Maharishi during a 1979 visit to Maharishi University of Management in Fairfield, Iowa]] In the mid 1970s, the Maharishi's U.S. movement was operating 370 TM centres manned by 6,000 TM teachers. At that time, the Maharishi also began approaching the business community via an organisation called the American Foundation for SCI (AFSCI), whose objective was to eliminate stress for business professionals. His TM movement came to be increasingly structured along the lines of a [[multinational corporation]]. The teaching of TM and the Science of Creative Intelligence in a New Jersey public school was stopped when a US court, in 1977, declared the movement to be religious, and ruled adoption of TM by public organisations in breach of the separation of church and state ([[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]).{{cite news|title=Trance 101|first=Mel |last=Bezalel|work=Jerusalem Post|date=1 May 2009|page=14}} During the 1980s, the organisation continued to expand and his meditation technique continued to attract celebrities despite its "outlandish claims" and accusations of fraud from disaffected former disciples.{{cite news|date=7 February 2008|title=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi|work=The Times|location=London (UK)|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article3320882.ece}} The TM organization made a number of property investments, buying a former Rothschild mansion in England, [[Mentmore Towers]] in Buckinghamshire, Roydon Hall in [[Maidstone]], Swythamley Park in the [[Peak District]], and a Georgian rectory in [[Suffolk]]. In the United States, resorts and hotels, many in city centres, were purchased to be used as TM training centres. [[Doug Henning]] and the Maharishi planned a magical Vedic amusement park, Vedaland, and bought large tracts of land near [[Orlando, Florida]], and [[Niagara Falls, Ontario]], to host the park. The theme park was supposed to be a gateway into understanding the mysteries of the universe. According to the Maharishi's official Vedic city website, "Entering Veda Land through a secret cave on a windswept plateau high in the Himalayas the adventure starts as one travels through a waterfall that leads to a forest where an ancient Vedic civilization awaits to reveal the deepest secrets of the universe (sic)".{{cite web|url=http://www.maharishivediccity-iowa.gov/amenities/vedaland.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424114004/http://www.maharishivediccity-iowa.gov/amenities/vedaland.html |archivedate=24 April 2016 |df=dmy }} These plans were never executed and, for Niagara Falls, Veda Land turned out to be just another theme park proposal that never materialized, joining an eclectic list that includes the Worlds of Jules Verne, the Ancient Chinese City and even Canada's Wonderland when it was first being planned.http://www.niagarafallsreview.ca/2008/02/08/a-dreamland-by-the-qew{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The Maharishi commissioned plans from a prominent architect for the [[Maharishi Sthapatya Veda#Peace Tower project|world's tallest building]], a Vedic-style pyramid to be built in [[São Paulo]], Brazil, and to be filled with Yogic Flyers and other TM endeavours.{{cite news|title=La Jolla resident involved with maharishi in plans for world's tallest high-rise, Brazil project expected to cost $1.6 billion|first=Frank Dirceu|last=Braun|work=The San Diego Union-Tribune|date=7 August 1999|page=A.12}} The Maharishi founded Maharishi Ved Vigyan Vishwa Vidyapeetham, a self-described educational institution located in [[Uttar Pradesh]], India, in 1982. The institution reports that it has trained 50,000 pundits in traditional Vedic recitation.Unknown author [http://www.e-gyan.net/mvvvv.jsp E-Gyan web site] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017004830/http://www.e-gyan.net/mvvvv.jsp |date=17 October 2015 }} accessed March 9, 2013Unknown author [http://www.maharishi-india.org/institutions/i6/index.html MVVVP Maharishi India web site] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515200556/http://www.maharishi-india.org/institutions/i6/index.html |date=15 May 2013 }} accessed March 9, 2013 In 1983, the Maharishi invited government leaders to interact with his organization called "World Government". In January 1988, offices at the Maharishinagar complex in New Delhi were raided by Indian tax authorities and the Maharishi and his organisation were accused of falsifying expenses.{{cite news|title=India: 'Buried' holy man fosters skepticism|first=Bryan |last=Johnson |work=The Globe and Mail|date=1 March 1988|page=A.8}} Reports on the value of stocks, fixed-deposit notes, cash and jewels confiscated, vary from source to source.{{cite news|title=Canadians urged to help build guru's heavenly housing|first=Shaun |last=Waters|work=The Globe and Mail|date=11 April 1988|page=A.13}}{{Cite news|last=Ehmann|first=James|title=Ehmann's People|work=The Post-Standard (Syracuse, NY)|date=5 May 1988 |page=A2|quote=Sub-head: We'll Transcend Our Mistake. "$60,000 in undeclared cash and jewelry were confiscated.}}{{cite news|title=Von Bulow Lawsuit is Settled |first=W.|last= Speers|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=24 December 1987|page=C02}}{{Cite news|last=Ehmann|first=James|title=Ehmann's People|work=The Post-Standard (Syracuse, NY)|date=5 May 1988 |page=A2|quote=Sub-head: We'll Transcend Our Mistake. Section: Back in December, we repeated a wire service's assertion that offices in India of the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi had been raided and that $60,000 in undeclared cash and jewelry were confiscated. Recently, we heard from the Age of Enlightenment News Service in Livingston Manor, which asserted that, according to "official documents from the Indian government", nothing of value was confiscated in the raids.}} The Maharishi, who was "headquartered in Switzerland" at the time, reportedly moved to the Netherlands "after the Indian government accused him of tax fraud".{{cite news|title=Natural Law confident its 'new knowledge' can solve the nation's problems|first=Mark |last=Richardson|work=The Ottawa Citizen. |date=16 October 1993|page=A.9}}) Following an earthquake in Armenia, the Maharishi trained Russian TM teachers and set up a Maharishi Ayurveda training centre in the Urals region.{{cite web|url=http://www.passportmagazine.ru/article/1846/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809143247/http://www.passportmagazine.ru/article/1846/ |archivedate=9 August 2016 |df=dmy }} Passport Magazine, Transcendental Meditation in Russia, Charles W. Borden, 8 Jul 2010, Retrieved 30 April 2011 Beginning in 1989, the Maharishi's movement began incorporating the term "Maharishi" into the names of their new and existing entities, concepts and programmes.{{cite book|pages=272–273|first=Paul|last=Mason|year=1994|publisher=Element |isbn=1-85230-571-1|title=The Maharishi}} ===Years in Vlodrop (1991–2008)=== [[File:20130723 MERU (Maharishi European Research University) in Vlodrop Holland - CC BY-NC-ND 1000x368.jpg|thumb|220px|left|The Maharishi's headquarters in MERU, The Netherlands]] In 1990, the Maharishi relocated his headquarters from [[Seelisberg]], Switzerland, to a former Franciscan monastery in [[Vlodrop]], the [[Netherlands]], which became known as [[MERU, Holland]], on account of the [[Maharishi European Research University]] (MERU) campus there.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,328965,00.html|title=Beatles Meditation Guru Maharishi Mahesh Yogi Dies|agency=AP|date=6 February 2008|publisher=Fox News}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/feb/06/musicnews.india|title=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, in peace|first=Martin |last=Hodgson|work=Guardian|location=UK|date=6 February 2008}} During his time in Vlodrop, he communicated to the public mainly via video and the internet. He also created a subscription-based, satellite TV channel, called Veda Vision, which broadcast content in 22 languages and 144 countries. In 1991, the Maharishi called Washington D.C. a "pool of mud" after a decade of attempts to lower the rate of crime in the city, which had the second-largest TM community in the US. He told his followers to leave and save themselves from its "criminal atmosphere".{{cite news|title=Head for the Hills, Disciples!; TM's Maharishi Holds Out No Hope for D.C.|first=Jim |last=Naughton|work=The Washington Post|date=16 December 1991|page=a.01|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/74759258.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT}} The Maharishi is believed to have made his final public appearance in 1991, in [[Maastricht]], the Netherlands.{{cite news|title=Real lives: Holy man of Maastricht: Since George Harrison's death, the papers have been full of pictures of him with his Indian guru in the 60s. So what is the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi up to these days? Andrew Osborn tracks him down – to Holland|first=Andrew|last=Osborn|work=The Guardian|location=Manchester (UK)|date=4 December 2001|page=4}} [[Deepak Chopra]], described as "one of the Maharishi's top assistants before he launched his own career", wrote that the Maharishi collapsed in 1991 with kidney and pancreas failure, that the illness was kept secret by the Maharishi's family and that he tended to Maharishi during a year-long recovery. According to Chopra, the Maharishi accused him, in July 1993, of trying to compete for the position of guru and asked him to stop travelling and writing books, which led to Chopra's decision to leave the movement in January 1994.{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/deepak-chopra/the-maharishi-years-the_b_86412.html|title=The Maharishi Years – The Untold Story: Recollections of a Former Disciple|first=Deepak|last=Chopra|date=13 February 2008|publisher=Huffington Post}} As part of a world plan for peace, the Maharishi inaugurated the [[Natural Law Party]] (NLP) and calling it a "natural government". His adherents founded the NLP in 1992.{{cite news|title=Don't Take It Personal: Meditation Technique Advocates Bring You Natural Law Party|first=Scott|last=Maier|work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer|date=22 September 1992|page=b.1}} It was active in forty-two countries.{{cite news|title=Imagine You Are Our Next President Meditation Is Key In Third-Party Bid. Series: Another in an occasional series of profiles of long-shot candidates for president.|first=Brigid|last=Schulte|work=The Record|location=Bergen County, N.J.|date=23 June 1996|page=32}} [[John Hagelin]], the NLP's three-time candidate for U.S. president, denied any formal connection between the Maharishi and the party.{{cite news|title=New laid-back national party calls philosophy only natural|first=Phoebe Wall|last=Howard|work=The Fresno Bee|location=Fresno, Calif.|date=8 January 1996|page=A.1}} According to spokesman Bob Roth, "The Maharishi has said the party has to grow to encompass everyone". Critics charged that the party was an effort to recruit people for Transcendental Meditation,{{cite news|title=Party of the flying yogics gets a free ride from the taxpayers|first=Chris|last=Cobb|work=The Vancouver Sun|date=30 October 1993|page=A.10}} and that it resembled "the political arm of an international corporation" more than a "home-grown political creation".{{cite news|title=Veda Land: The New Incarnation of the Maharishi: Rejection by the voters only serves to make the Natural Law Party's appeals more urgent, its plans more grandiose, its claims more strident|first=Jack|last=Kapica|work=The Globe and Mail|location=Toronto, Ont.|date=27 November 1993|page=D.3}} The Indian arm of the NLP, the Ajeya Bharat Party, achieved electoral success, winning one seat in a state assembly in 1998.{{Cite web|title=Madhya Pradesh: State Election Of 25 November 1998|publisher=Psephos|accessdate=31 December 2009|url=http://psephos.adam-carr.net/countries/i/india/states/madh1.txt}} The Maharishi shut down the political effort in 2004, saying, "I had to get into politics to know what is wrong there."{{cite news|title=Indian guru who taught the Beatles sets sights on Canada|first=James|last=Keller|work=The Globe and Mail|location=Toronto, Ont.|date=17 October 2005|page=A.8}} In 1992, the Maharishi began to send groups of [[TM-Sidhi programme|Yogic Flyers]] to countries like India, Brazil, China and America in an effort to promote world peace through "coherent world consciousness". In 1993 and 2003, he decided to raise the fees for learning the TM technique.{{cite news|last=Naedele|first=Walter Jr.|title=Meditation program goes from 'Om' to 'Ouch'|work=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=30 August 1994|page=B.2}}{{cite news|last=Overton|first=Penelope|title=Group promotes meditation therapy in schools|work=Hartford Courant|date=15 September 2003|page=B1}}{{cite news|last=Greening|first=Benedict|title=TM courses halted as fees soar|work=Royal Gazette|location=Bermuda|date=16 August 2003}} In 1997 the Maharishi's organization built the largest wooden structure in the Netherlands without using any nails.{{cite news|title=MY AUDIENCE WITH THE YOGI ; Whatever became of the Maharishi who bewitched The Beatles with his mystical teachings on meditation? DAVID JONES tracked him down to his bizarre private kingdom (complete with its own currency) where he conducted one of the most extraordinary interviews of his career|first=David |last=Jones|work=Daily Mail|location=London (UK)|date=March 18, 2006|page=34}}{{cite news|title=[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-512747/Lennon-right-The-Giggling-Guru-shameless-old-fraud.html Lennon was right. The Giggling Guru was a shameless old fraud]|first=David |last=Jones|work=Daily Mail|location=London (UK)|date=February 7, 2008|page=22}} The building was the Maharishi's residence for the last two decades of his life. In later years, the Maharishi rarely left his two-room quarters in order to preserve his health and energy.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/08/magazine/08wwln_essay.html?_r=1&oref=slogin| work=The New York Times|title=Encounter: Outer Peace |first=LILY |last=KOPPEL|date=October 8, 2006}} He used videoconferencing to communicate with the world and with his advisors.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/aug/15/health.healthandwellbeing |title=All you need is love and peace - but not in destructive Britain, so maharishi pulls out: Followers split as 95-year-old guru ends meditation teaching in 'scorpion nation'|first=Mark |last=Honigsbaum|work=The Guardian, London (UK)|date=August 15, 2005|page=3}} Built to [[Maharishi Sthapatya Veda]] architectural standards, the structure, according to the Maharishi, is said to have helped him infuse "the light of Total Knowledge" into "the destiny of the human race".{{cite press release|url=http://www.globalgoodnews.com/health-news-a.html?art=1181073654230287|title=Global Reconstruction will provide fortunate living conditions for everyone|date=June 5, 2007|publisher=Global Good News Service}}{{Cite book|last=Williamson|first=Lola |title=Transcendent in America:Hindu-Inspired Meditation Movements as New Religion |publisher=NYU Press|year=2010|isbn=978-0-8147-9450-0}} In 2000, the Maharishi founded the [[Global Country of World Peace]] (GCWP) "to create global world peace by unifying all nations in happiness, prosperity, invincibility and perfect health, while supporting the rich diversity of our world family".{{Cite web|url=http://globalcountryofworldpeace.org/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sMQwFTnB?url=http://globalcountryofworldpeace.org/|archivedate=30 August 2010|title=Global Country of World Peace: Welcome|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} The Maharishi crowned [[Tony Nader]], a physician and MIT-trained neuroscientist, as the king or [[Maharaja]] of the GCWP in 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalcountry.org/wp/full-width/global-administration/|title=Global Organization|accessdate=31 December 2013}} The GCWP unsuccessfully attempted to establish a sovereign [[micronation]] when it offered US$1.3 billion to the President of [[Suriname]] for a 200-year lease of {{convert|3500|acre|km2}} of land and in 2002, attempted to choose a king for the [[Talamanca (canton)|Talamanca]], a "remote Indian reservation" in [[Costa Rica]].{{cite news|url=http://www.lafogata.org/02latino/6latinoamerica/indigenas.htm|title=Costa Rica: Secta divide a indígenas|date=24 July 2002|work=La Fogata|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sMbeFgke?url=http://www.lafogata.org/02latino/6latinoamerica/indigenas.htm|archivedate=30 August 2010|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://groups.google.com/group/alt.meditation.transcendental/msg/ac69445750efc3a2|work=AP World Politics|date=18 July 2002|title=Costa Rica expels foreigners for naming king of remote Indian reservation|quote=It was obvious that they were promoting an independent state within Costa Rica, and we can't tolerate that" said the Central American nation's security minister Rogelio Ramos.}} Shorter version at {{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2002-07-19/news/0207190107_1_rica-indian-reservation-unrest |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617164345/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2002-07-19/news/0207190107_1_rica-indian-reservation-unrest |archivedate=17 June 2016 |df=dmy }} In 2001, followers of the Maharishi founded [[Maharishi Vedic City]] a few miles north of [[Fairfield, Iowa]], in the United States. This new city requires that the construction of its homes and buildings be done according to the Maharishi Sthapatya Veda principles of "harmony with nature".{{cite news|url=http://www.newsvine.com/_news/2008/02/05/1280564-beatles-guru-maharishi-mahesh-yogi-dies|work=Newsvine|title=Beatles Guru Maharishi Mahesh Yogi Dies|agency=Associated Press|date=5 February 2008}} [[File:MaharishiMaheshYogi-06.jpg|thumb|The Maharishi in 2007]] In a 2002 appearance on the CNN show, ''[[Larry King Live]]'', the first time in twenty-five years that the Maharishi had appeared in the mainstream media, he said "Transcendental Meditation is something that can be defined as a means to do what one wants to do in a better way, a right way, for maximum results". It was occasioned by the reissue of the Maharishi's book ''The Science of Being and Art of Living''.{{Cite book| publisher=The MIT Press| isbn=0-262-55065-2| last=Easterling| first=Keller| title=Enduring Innocence: Global Architecture and Its Political Masquerades| date=31 October 2007}} That same year, the [[Maharishi Global Financing Research Foundation]] issued the "[[Global Country of World Peace#Currency|Raam]]" as a currency "dedicated to financing peace promoting projects". In 2003, [[David Lynch]] began a fundraising project to raise US$1 billion "on behalf of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi" to build a meditation centre large enough to hold 8,000 skilled practitioners.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2003/dec/10/davidlynch |work=The Guardian|title=Peace Man|first=Julian |last=Borger|date=10 December 2003 | location=London}} The Maharishi ordered a suspension of TM training in Britain in 2005 due to his opposition to prime minister [[Tony Blair]]'s decision to support the Iraq War. The Maharishi said that he did not want to waste the "beautiful nectar" of TM on a "scorpion nation".{{cite web|archivedate=11 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5usqfKWfg?url=http://www.press-conference.globalgoodnews.com/archive/may/05.05.11.html|url=http://www.press-conference.globalgoodnews.com/archive/may/05.05.11.html|date=11 May 2005|title=Press Conference Highlights|publisher=globalgoodnews.com|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} He lifted the ban after Blair's resignation in 2007.{{cite news |url=http://www.champnews.com/html/newsstory.asp?id=5943 |first=Richard |last=Lackey |title=Skelmersdale's yogic flyers |date=8 August 2007 |work=Champion |location=Southport, UK |archivedate=11 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5usrF3sPW?url=http://www.champnews.com/html/newsstory.asp?id=5943 |deadurl=yes |df= }} During this period, skeptics were critical of some of the Maharishi's programmes, such as a $10 trillion plan to end poverty through organic farming in poor countries and a $1 billion plan to use meditation groups to end conflict. ===Death=== Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, concerned about his health,{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/feb/19/news/adfg-yogi19|title=A Yogi's Plan for Today's Troubled World|first=Arthur|last=Max|work=Los Angeles Times|agency=Associated Press|date=19 February 2006}} became increasingly secluded in two rooms of his residence. During this period he rarely had in-person meetings and instead communicated with his followers almost exclusively by closed-circuit television.{{cite news|title=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, a Guide on the Beatles' Spiritual Path, Dies|first=Lily|last=Koppel|work=New York Times|date=6 February 2008|page=C.10|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/06/world/asia/06maharishi-1.html?_r=1}} On 12 January 2008, his ninetieth birthday, the Maharishi declared: "It has been my pleasure at the feet of Guru Dev ([[Brahmananda Saraswati]]), to take the light of Guru Dev and pass it on in my environment. Now today, I am closing my designed duty to Guru Dev. And I can only say, 'Live long the world in peace, happiness, prosperity, and freedom from suffering.'"{{cite news|url=http://www.globalgoodnews.com/world-peace-a.html?art=12006132879728764|title=Inauguration of Maharishi's Year of Invincibility – Global Raam Raj: Rejoicing in the supreme fulfilment of Invincibility for the world – Global Country of World Peace celebrates the dawn of administration of eternal silence|publisher=Global Good News|accessdate=2010-09-01|date=12 January 2008}}{{cite news|url=http://www.globalgoodnews.com/world-peace-a.html?art=12005179678680766|title=Historic address of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi on 11 January 2008|date=11 January 2008|publisher=Global Good News}}{{cite press release|publisher=invincibleamerica.org|title=Dear Fellow Governors, Sidhas and Meditators of America|first=John|last=Hagelin|date=8 January 2008|url=http://www.randi.org/jr/2008-01/JaiGuruDev.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sPXjd86O?url=http://www.randi.org/jr/2008-01/JaiGuruDev.html|archivedate=1 September 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} A week before his death, the Maharishi said that he was "stepping down as leader of the TM movement" and "retreating into silence" and that he planned to spend his remaining time studying "the ancient Indian texts". The Maharishi died peacefully in his sleep of natural causes on 5 February 2008 at his residence in Vlodrop, Netherlands.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7229597.stm |work=BBC News|title=Indian guru Maharishi Yogi dies|date=6 February 2008}} The cremation and funeral rites were conducted at the Maharishi's [[Allahabad]] ashram in India, overlooking the confluence of the [[Ganges]] and [[Yamuna]] rivers.[http://www.indiaenews.com/religion/20080211/96901.htm India eNews, Madhusree Chatterjee, February 11, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310150553/http://www.indiaenews.com/religion/20080211/96901.htm |date=10 March 2012 }}[http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-31869420080211 "The Beatles' guru Maharishi Mahesh Yogi cremated", Krittivas Mukherjee, Reuters, Feb 11, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303180848/http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-31869420080211 |date=3 March 2016 }} The funeral, with state honours,[https://archive.is/20120802074354/http://www.hindujagruti.org/news/3925.html Hindu Janajagruti Samiti, "Maharishi Mahesh Yogi cremated", February 11, 2008] was carried by Sadhana TV station and was presided over by one of the claimants to the seat of Shankaracharya of the North, Swami Vasudevananda Saraswati Maharaj.Williamson, Lola (2012) New York University Press, Transcendent in America, pp 80–105 (page 80) Indian officials who attended the funeral included central minister Subodh Kant Sahay; Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP) leader Ashok Singhal; and former Uttar Pradesh assembly speaker and state BJP leader Keshri Nath Tripathi, as well as top local officials.{{cite book |first=Soren |last=Brier |chapter=The Conflict between Indian Vedic Mentality and Western Modernity |title=Mentality and Thought: North, South, East and West |editor-first=Per |editor-last=Durst-Anderson |editor2-first=Elsebeth |editor2-last=Lange |year=2010 |location=Copenhagen |publisher=Copenhagen Business School Press |pages=53–86}} Also in attendance were thirty-five rajas of the Global Country of World Peace, one-time disciple [[Ravi Shankar (spiritual leader)|Sri Sri Ravi Shankar]], and [[David Lynch]]. A troop of uniformed policemen lowered their arms in salute.{{cite news|title=Mahesh Yogi cremated with state honours|work=The Hindustan Times|location=New Delhi|date=11 February 2008}} The funeral received its status as a state funeral because the Maharishi was a recognised master in the tradition of [[Advaita Vedanta]] founded by Shankara. The Maharishi is survived by a brother and "a number of nephews".{{cite news|title=Mahesh Yogi cremated as large gathering pays tribute|first1=Sharat|last1=Pradhanl|first2=Madhusree|last2=Chatterjee|work=IANS|url=http://www.indianmuslims.info/news/2008/feb/11/mahesh_yogi_cremated_large_gathering_pays_tribute.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601002812/http://www.indianmuslims.info/news/2008/feb/11/mahesh_yogi_cremated_large_gathering_pays_tribute.html|archivedate=1 June 2011|df=dmy-all}} One nephew, Girish Chandra Varma,{{cite news|title=Veneration marks 'Shodashi Sanskar'|work=The Hindustan Times|location=New Delhi|date=20 February 2008}} is chairman of the [[Maharishi Vidya Mandir Schools|Maharishi Vidya Mandir Schools Group]][http://maharishividyamandir.com/chairmanDesk.jsp Brahmachari Girish (Dr Girish Chandra Varma)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728074740/http://maharishividyamandir.com/chairmanDesk.jsp |date=28 July 2011 }}, accessed April 22, 2013{{cite news|url=http://www.e-gyan.net/November09/picture/E-GyanNovember.pdf|work=E-Gyan|issue=5|date=12 November 2009|title=Maharishi National Cultural Celebration – 2009|format=PDF|access-date=1 February 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723104407/http://www.e-gyan.net/November09/picture/E-GyanNovember.pdf|archive-date=23 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} and a "senior functionary of the Transcendental Meditation (TM) movement in India." Other nephews include Prakash Shrivastav,{{cite news|title=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi to be cremated in grand ceremony|first=Sharat|last=Pradhan|date=10 February 2008|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2008/feb/10look.htm|publisher=Rediff.com|accessdate=6 April 2010}} president of Maharishi Vidya Mandir Schools{{Cite web|title=About Chairman |publisher=Maharishi Vidya Mandir public school |url=http://www.mvmpslko.com/chairman.html |accessdate=6 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901083720/http://www.mvmpslko.com/chairman.html |archivedate=1 September 2009 }} and Anand Shrivastava,{{Cite web|first=Deepak|last=Chopra|date=13 February 2008|title=The Maharishi Years – The Untold Story: Recollections of a Former Disciple|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/deepak-chopra/the-maharishi-years-the-u_b_86412.html?page=2&show_comment_id=11483686#comment_11483686|accessdate=5 April 2010|publisher=Huffington Post}} chairman of the [[Maharishi Group]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.rrcap.unep.org/uneptg05/resource/anand.htm |publisher=UNEP-Tongji Institute of Environment for Sustainable Development |title=Human Dimension: Anand Shrivastava |accessdate=5 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sbigBEQf?url=http://www.rrcap.unep.org/uneptg05/resource/anand.htm |archivedate=9 September 2010 |df= }} In its obituary, [[BBC News]] reported that the Maharishi's master had bequeathed him "the task of keeping the tradition of Transcendental Meditation alive" and that "the Maharishi's commercial mantras drew criticism from stricter Hindus, but his promises of better health, stress relief and spiritual enlightenment drew devotees from all over the world". [[Paul McCartney]] commented saying that "Whilst I am deeply saddened by his passing, my memories of him will only be joyful ones. He was a great man who worked tirelessly for the people of the world and the cause of unity."{{cite web|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gRZCe-4LSHJgdhhiNS3N5ltwglNA |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130429223746/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gRZCe-4LSHJgdhhiNS3N5ltwglNA |archivedate=29 April 2013 |df=dmy }} "Beatles pay tribute to late Maharishi Mahesh Yogi", ''AFP'' (7 February 2008) ===Legacy=== The Maharishi left a legacy that includes the revival of India's ancient spiritual tradition of meditation, which he made available to everyone.{{cite book|last=Greenberg|first=Jerrold S.|title=Comprehensive Stress Management|year=2006|publisher=McGraw-Hill}} He is considered responsible for the popularisation of meditation in the west,{{cite web | title=Mantras that made Maharishi's mission successful | publisher=Hindustan Times | date=Feb 8, 2008 }}James Dalen, James and Devries, Stephen (2011) Oxford University Press (New York) ''Integrative Cardiology,'' The Integrative Approach to Hypertension, Ch. 11, page 237 something he accomplished by teaching Transcendental Meditation worldwide through a highly effective organization of his own development. The Maharishi is also credited with "the proposal of the existence of a unique or fourth state of consciousness with a basis in physiology" and the application of scientific studies to research on the physiological effects of Transcendental Meditation and the development of higher states of consciousness, areas previously relegated to mysticism.Wagger, Lane (16 June 2011) [http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/The-prime-mover-of-life/articleshow/7310685.cms The prime mover of life] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017004829/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/The-prime-mover-of-life/articleshow/7310685.cms |date=17 October 2015 }}, ''Times of India''{{cite book|last=Goldberg |first=Philip |title=American Veda|year=2011 |publisher=Harmony Books|page=173}}Rosenthal, Norman (2011) Tarcher Books, Transcendence, page 4{{cite book |last1=Jevning|first1=Ronald|authorlink1=|last2=Walsh|first2=Deane H|authorlink2= |editor1-first=Deane H |editor1-last= Shapiro |others=Roger Walsh|title= Meditation: Classic and Contemporary Perspectives|trans-title= |year= 1984|publisher= Aldine Publishing Company|location= Hawthorne, New York|language= |isbn= 0-202-25136-5|oclc= |page= 470 |chapter= Chapter 33: Metabolic Effects of Transcendental Meditation: Toward a New Paradigm of Neurobiology}} Partly because of this, ''Newsweek'' credited him with helping to launch "a legitimate new field of neuroscience".Begley, Sharon (18 February 2008). "His Magical Mystery Tour". Newsweek: 18. "Whatever you think of the 'White Album', give the Maharishi credit for helping launch what's become a legitimate new field of neuroscience." According to the ''[[Times of India]]'' his "unique and enduring contribution to humankind was his deep understanding of – and mechanics of experiencing – pure consciousness". A memorial building, the Maharishi Smarak, was inaugurated at [[Allahabad]] in February 2013.{{cite web | url=http://www.maharishivastu.org/newsletter/owning-vastu-2013_03.html | title=Maharishi Smarak Inaugurated | publisher=maharishivastu.org | date=March 2013 | accessdate=2015-09-04 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.indiapost.com/maharishi-smarak-inaugurated-during-kumbh-mela/|title=Maharishi Smarak inaugurated during Kumbh Mela|date=April 10, 2013|work=India Post|accessdate=27 November 2013}} ==Philosophy and teaching== {{Hindu philosophy}} The Maharishi had come out to teach with the "avowed intention" to change "the course of human history". When he first began teaching he had three main aims: to revive the spiritual tradition in India, to show that meditation was for everyone and not just for recluses, and to show that Vedanta is compatible with science.Goldberg, (2010) ''American Veda'', New York, Harmony Books pp154-155. The Maharishi had a message of happiness, writing in 1967 that "being happy is of the utmost importance. Success in anything is through happiness. Under all circumstances be happy. Just think of any negativity that comes at you as a raindrop falling into the ocean of your bliss". His philosophy featured the concept that "within everyone is an unlimited reservoir of energy, intelligence, and happiness". He emphasised the naturalness of his meditation technique as a simple way of developing this potential.{{cite book|title=The many colors of Hinduism|first=Carl |last=Olsen|pages=338–341|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RVWKClYq4TUC|year=2007|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=978-0-8135-4068-9}} Beginning in 1962, the Maharishi began to recommend the daily practice of yoga exercises or [[asanas]] to further accelerate growth.Mason, p. 59 (1994) He also taught that practising Transcendental Meditation twice a day would create inner peace and that "mass meditation sessions" could create outer peace by reducing violence and war. According to a TM website, the performance of [[yajna|yagya]]s by 7,000 [[pandit]]s in India, plus hundreds of Yogic Flyers in Germany, brought "coherence and unity in the collective consciousness of Germany" and caused the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]].{{Cite web|title=Maharishi's Programme to Create World Peace led to fall of Berlin Wall: Rising coherence in national and world consciousness|publisher=Global Good News|date=9 November 2009|accessdate=29 August 2010|url=http://www.globalgoodnews.com/world-peace-a.html?art=12578119332103873|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724122036/http://www.globalgoodnews.com/world-peace-a.html?art=12578119332103873|dead-url=no|archivedate=24 July 2011}}{{cite book|last=Gardner|first=Martin |title=Weird water & fuzzy logic: more notes of a fringe watcher|year=1996|publisher=Prometheus Books|isbn=1573920967|page=142}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1990-11-03/news/9002230201_1_transcendental-meditation-mass-meditation-maharishi-mahesh-yogi|title=U.s. Meditation Believers Seek To Give Peace A Chant|last=Cummins|first=Ken|date=November 3, 1990|work=Sun Sentinel|accessdate=9 May 2013}} One religion scholar, Michael York, considers the Maharishi to have been the most articulate spokesman for the spiritual argument that a critical mass of people becoming enlightened through the practice of "meditation and yogic discipline" will trigger the New Age movement's hoped-for period of [[postmillennial]] "peace, harmony, and collective consciousness".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nng-dAooleAC&pg=PA17&dq=Maharishi+millennialism&cd=7#v=onepage&q=&f=false | editor-last = Barger | editor-first = Helen A. | last=York|first=Michael|chapter=New Age and Magic|page=16|title = Witchcraft and Magic: Contemporary North America | publisher = University of Pennsylvania Press | year = 2006 | isbn = 978-0-8122-1971-5 | work = books.google.com | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }} Religious studies scholar Carl Olson writes that the TM technique was based on "a neo-Vedanta metaphysical philosophy in which an unchanging reality is opposed to an ever-changing phenomenal world" and that the Maharishi says it is not necessary to renounce worldly activities to gain enlightenment, unlike other ascetic traditions. According to author Jack Forem, the Maharishi stated that the experience of transcendence, which resulted in a naturally increasing refinement of mind and body, enabled people to naturally behave in more correct ways. Thus, behavioral guidelines did not need to be issued, and were best left to the teachings of various religions: "It is much easier to raise a man's consciousness than to get him to act righteously" the Maharishi said.{{cite book|last=Forem|first=Jack|title=Transcendental Meditation-The classic text revised and updated|edition=2nd|year=2012|publisher=Hay House, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4019-3156-8|page=250}} Some religious studies scholars have further said that Maharishi Mahesh Yogi is one of a number of Indian [[guru]]s who brought [[Hinduism in the West|neo-Hindu]] adaptations of [[Vedantic Hinduism]] to the west.{{Cite book|editor-first=Jacob |editor-last=Neusner|first=Gerald James|last=Larson|chapter=Hinduism in India and in America|title=World Religions in America: An Introduction|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|year=2009|isbn=978-0-664-23320-4|page=192}}{{cite book|last=Alper|first=Harvey P.|title=Understanding mantras|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V8Upy4ApG_oC&pg=PA442|date=December 1991|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ.|isbn=978-81-208-0746-4|page=442}}{{cite book|last1=Raj|first1=Selva J.|author2=William P. Harman|title=Dealing With Deities: The Ritual Vow in South Asia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ov2oltTLinkC&pg=PA129|year=2007|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-0-7914-6708-4|page=129}} Author [[Meera Nanda]] calls neo-Hinduism "the brand of Hinduism that is taught by Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, Deepak Chopra, and their clones".{{Cite book| publisher = Rutgers University Press | isbn = 978-0-8135-3357-5| last = Nanda| first = Meera|title = Prophets facing backward: postmodern critiques of science and Hindu nationalism in India| location = Piscataway N.J.; London|year = 2004|page=46}} J. R. Coplin, a sociologist and MIU graduate, says that the Maharishi saw his own purpose as "the 'revival' of the knowledge of an integrated life based upon Vedic principles and Vedantist reality". Author Barry Miles writes that, in spite of the media's scepticism for the Maharishi's spiritual message, they seized upon him because young people seemed to listen to his pro-establishment, anti-drug message with one TM participant saying the Maharishi "signaled the beginning of the post-acid generation". ===Transcendental Meditation=== {{Main|Transcendental Meditation}} During a CNN interview in 2002, the Maharishi said "Transcendental meditation is something that can be defined as a means to do what one wants to do in a better way, a right way, for maximum results". His movement offered in-residence style TM advanced courses.{{cite press release|url=http://www.invincibleamerica.org/press/2006_07_25.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sPYDqhks?url=http://invincibleamerica.org/press/2006_07_25.html|archivedate=1 September 2010|title=More than 1200 Yogic Flyers Assemble in Washington, D.C., and Iowa to Promote Invincibility in America and Permanent World Peace|publisher=Invincible America|date=25 July 2006|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} By the time of his death, there were nearly 1,000 TM training centres around the world. The Maharishi is credited as having contributed to the western world a meditation technique that is both simple and systematic as well as introducing the scientific study of meditation.{{cite book|last=Goldberg|first=Phiilip|title=American Veda|year=2010|publisher=Harmony Books|location=New York|isbn=978-0-385-52134-5|page=163}} In the mid 1970s, the Maharishi began the [[TM-Sidhi program]]me, which included Yogic Flying, as an additional option for those who had been practising the Transcendental Meditation technique for some time. According to Coplin, this new aspect of knowledge emphasised not only the individual, but also the collective benefits created by group practice of this advanced programme.Coplin, J. R. (1990) p. 71 {{Request quotation|date=March 2010}} This new programme gave rise to a new principle called the ''[[Transcendental Meditation#Maharishi Effect|Maharishi Effect]]'', which is said to "create coherence in the collective consciousness" and to suppress crime, violence, and accidents.{{cite news|title=Musicians Spread the Maharishi's Message of Peace|first=GREGG |last=WAGER|work=Los Angeles Times |date=11 December 1987|page=12}} ===Maharishi Vedic Science=== [[File:Maharishi Vedic University in Holland.JPG|thumb|Entrance to the Maharishi University of Management and Maharishi Vedic University campus in Vlodrop, the Netherlands]] Maharishi Vedic Science (MVS) is based on the Maharishi's interpretation of the ancient Vedic texts based on his master, [[Brahmananda Saraswati]]'s teachings.Humes 2005 p. 66. MVS aims to put forward traditional Vedic literature in the light of Western traditions of knowledge and understanding.{{cite book|last=Meyer-Dinkgräfe|first=Daniel |title=Theatre And Consciousness: Explanatory Scope And Future Potential|year=2005|publisher=Intellect Books|isbn=1841501301|pages=appendix p1}} According to [[Roy Ascott]], MVS also explains the potential for every human being to experience the infinite nature of transcendental consciousness, also defined as Being or Self, while engaged in normal activities of daily life.{{cite book|last=Ascott|first=Roy|title=Reframing Consciousness : Art, Mind and Technology|year=2000|publisher=Intellect Books|isbn=1841508152 |pages=285–290}} Once this state is fully established an individual is no longer influenced by outer aspects of existence and perceives pure consciousness in everything. MVS includes two aspects, the practical aspect of the Transcendental Meditation technique and the TM-Sidhi programme, as well as the theoretical aspect of how MVS is applied to day to day living.{{Cite book|first1=Anna |last1=Bonshek|first2=Corrina |last2=Bonshek|first3=Lee C. |last3=Fergusson|title=The Big Fish: Consciousness as Structure, Body and Space|publisher=Rodopi|year=2007|series=Consciousness, literature & the arts |isbn=978-90-420-2172-3|pages=6–9}} These applications include programmes in: [[Maharishi Vedic Approach to Health]] (MVAH);{{Cite book|title=Contemporary Ayurveda, Medicine and Research in Maharishi Ayur-Veda|first1=H. |last1=Sharma |first2=Christopher |last2=Clark |year=1998|isbn=978-0-443-05594-2|chapter=Chapter 13: Maharishi's Vedic Approach to Health}}{{Cite book|first1=Robert H. |last1=Schneider|first2=Jeremy Z. |last2=Fields|title=Total Heart Health: How to Prevent and Reverse Heart Disease with the Maharishi Vedic Approach to Health|publisher=Basic Health Publications, Inc. |year=2006|isbn=978-1-59120-087-1}} [[Maharishi Sthapatya Veda]], a mathematical system for the design and construction of buildings;[http://download.tmnews.org/2005_08_05_RockIsArgus_ltr.pdf Welvaert, Brandy, Vedic homes seek better living through architecture", ''Rock Island Argus'', (August 5, 2005)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303202354/http://download.tmnews.org/2005_08_05_RockIsArgus_ltr.pdf |date=3 March 2016 }}{{cite news|work=Washington Post|title=Bricks Mortar and Serenity|first=Miranda|last=Spivack|date=September 12, 2008|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/12/11/AR2008121103497.html}} Maharishi Gandharva Veda,{{Cite book|title=The Physiology of Consciousness|first=Robert Keith |last=Wallace|isbn=978-0-923569-02-0|pages=99–102|publisher=Maharishi International University Press|year=1986}} a form of classical Indian music; Maharishi Jyotish (also known as Maharishi Vedic Astrology),Sharma & Clark (1998) pp. 143–145Wallace (1986) pp 107–109 a system claiming the evaluation of life tendencies of an individual; Maharishi Vedic Agriculture, a trademarked process for producing fresh, organic food; and Consciousness-Based Education.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=348&dat=19840224&id=NWdMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xjQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6149,856508|title=Meditation: Is it Really a Cure-all?
